context: All employees who schedule a meeting with their customers will appear in the company today. Everyone who has lunch in the company schedules meetings with their customers. Employees will either have lunch in the company or have lunch at home. If an employee has lunch at home, then he/she is working remotely from home. All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home. No managers work remotely from home. James is either a manager and appears in the company today or neither a manager nor appears in the company today.
question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? James does not have lunch in the company.

Predicates:
Appear(x) ::: x appears in the company today.
Lunch(x) ::: x has lunch in the company.
WorkRemotely(x) ::: x works remotely from home.
Manager(x) ::: x is a manager.
Premises:
∀x (Appear(x) → Lunch(x)) ::: All employees who schedule a meeting with their customers will appear in the company today.
∀x (Lunch(x) → WorkRemotely(x)) ::: Everyone who has lunch in the company schedules meetings with their customers.
∀x (WorkRemotely(x) → ¬Manager(x)) ::: Employees will either have lunch in the company or have lunch at home. If an employee has lunch at home, then he/she is working remotely from home.
∀x (WorkRemotely(x) → ¬Manager(x)) ::: All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home.
∀x (Appear(x) ⊕ WorkRemotely(x)) ::: No managers work remotely from home.
(Manager(james) ∧ Appear(james)) ⊕ ¬(Manager(james) ∨ Appear(james)) ::: James is either a manager and appears in the company today or neither a manager nor appears in the company today.
Conclusion:
Lunch(james) ⊕ WorkRemotely(james) ::: James does not have l

∀x (Work(x) → Remote(x)) ::: Employees will either have lunch in the company or have lunch at home.
∀x (Remote(x) → Manager(x)) ::: All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home.
∀x (Appear(x) ⊕ Remote(x)) ::: No managers work remotely from home.
(Appear(james) ∧ Remote(james)) ⊕ ¬(Appear(james) ∨ Remote(james)) ::: James is either a manager and appears in the company today or neither a manager nor appears in the company today.
Conclusion:

context: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events. People either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested members of their community. If people chaperone high school dances, then they are not students who attend the school. All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances. All young children and teenagers who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school. Bonnie either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school, or she neither attends and is very engaged with school events nor is a student who attends the school.
question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
raw_logic_programs:
Predicates:
Perform(x, y) ::: x performs in y.
Attend(x, y) ::: x attends y.
Engaged(x, y) ::: x is very engaged with y.
Chaperone(x, y) ::: x chaperones y.
Student(x) ::: x is a student.
Premises:
∀x (Perform(x, school) → Attend(x, school)) ::: If people perform in school talent shows often, then they attend and are very engaged with school events.
∀x (Attend(x, school) ⊕ Engaged(x, school)) ::: People either attend and are very engaged with school events or are inactive and disinterested members of their community.
∀x (Chaperone(x, highSchoolDance) → ¬Student(x)) ::: All people who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances.
∀x (Student(x) ∧ Attend(x, school)) ::: All young children and teenagers who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school.
Bonnie ⊕ Student(bonnie) ::: Bonnie either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school, or she neither attends and is very engaged with school events nor is a student who attends the school.
Conclusion:
Perform(bonnie, school) ::: Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
------

context: There are six types of wild turkeys: Eastern wild turkey, Osceola wild turkey, Gould’s wild turkey, Merriam’s wild turkey, Rio Grande wild turkey, and Ocellated wild turkey. question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Tom is an Ocellated wild turkey.
raw_logic_programs:

Goulds(x) ::: x is a Gould's wild turkey.
Merriams(x) ::: x is a Merriam's wild turkey.
RioGrande(x) ::: x is a Rio Grande wild turkey.
Ocellated(x) ::: x is an Ocellated wild turkey.
Premises:
∀x (WildTurkey(x) → ¬Eastern(x) ∨ ¬Osceola(x) ∨ ¬Goulds(x) ∨ ¬Merriams(x) ∨ ¬RioGrande(x)) ::: There are six types of wild turkeys: Eastern wild turkey, Osceola wild turkey, Gould’s wild turkey, Merriam’s wild turkey, Rio Grande wild turkey, and Ocellated wild turkey.
∀x (WildTurkey(x) → ¬Eastern(x) ∨ ¬Osceola(x) ∨ ¬Goulds(x) ∨ ¬Merriams(x) ∨ ¬RioGrande(x)) ::: There are six types of wild turkeys: Eastern wild turkey, Osceola wild turkey, Gould’s wild turkey, Merriam’s wild turkey, Rio Grande wild turkey, and Ocellated wild turkey.
